did.abstract: The papers document the business and personal life of Nathan Judson, his brother James B. Judson, and his nephews Wilber, Lowell, and Paul. Correspondence and financial records document the activity of the firms Judson, Wiley & Judson and Judson Brothers in late nineteenth-century and early twentieth-century Michigan, and the Judson Brothers fruit growing business in Kinderhook, New York. Correspondence documents the buying and selling of Michigan real estate, mining investments in various western states and Mexico (including the Buck Eye Mining Company in Basin, Montana and the Sierra Mining Company in Ocampo, Chihuahua, Mexico), and the horticulture business in the Hudson Valley of New York State in the 1910s and 1920s. Other than correspondence, the collection includes fragmentary financial records (including bank records and cancelled checks) and real estate documents (including deeds and abstracts to holdings in Michigan).

bioghist.head: Nathan Judson
bioghist.p: Nathan Judson was a real estate dealer in Lansing, Michigan. Together with his brother James B. Judson, he ran the firms Judson, Wiley & Judson, and Judson Brothers. In addition to buying and selling Michigan real estate, he invested in gold mines, including the Buck Eye Mining Company in Basin, Montana. After the death of James, he supported the education of his three nephews Wilber, Lowell, and Paul Judson. Wilber travelled extensively in the Western United States and in Mexico to investigate mining prospects on behalf of his uncle. Wilber worked at several mines, including the Buck Eye Mine in Basin, Montana (1902-1903), an unidentified mine in Panama (1905), and the Sierra Mining Company in Ocampo, Chihuahua, Mexico (1911). Paul and Lowell founded the Judson Brothers fruit growing business in Kinderhook, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers document the business and personal life of Nathan Judson, his brother James B. Judson, and his nephews Wilber, Lowell, and Paul. Correspondence and financial records document the activity of the firms Judson, Wiley & Judson and Judson Brothers, in late nineteenth-century and early twentieth-century Michigan. Correspondence documents the buying and selling of Michigan real estate, mining investments in various western states and Mexico (including the Buck Eye Mining Company in Basin, Montana and the Sierra Mining Company in Ocampo, Chihuahua, Mexico), and the horticulture business in the Hudson Valley of New York State in the 1910s and 1920s. Other than correspondence, the collection includes fragmentary financial records (including bank records and cancelled cheques) and real estate documents (including deeds and abstracts to holdings in Michigan).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Correspondence, 1880-1950. II. Financial and Real Estate Records, 1837-1902.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Early correspondence (before 1911) relates chiefly to Michigan real estate and includes letters sent to landowners, often in Eastern states, making offers on their holdings in Michigan. Correspondence from the 1900s and 1910s includes documentation of the Judsons' involvement in mining ventures. Much of the later correspondence relates to Nathan Judson's business and personal relationships with his three nephews: Wilber, Lowell, and Paul Judson.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two files by type of material: Real estate records, and Financial records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Real estate records include deeds and abstracts to lands purchased by Nathan Judson, Judson Brothers, and Judson, Wiley & Judson. Financial records consist chiefly of cancelled checks drawn on the Judson Brothers accounts.
